Yes, things aren't perfect here at home and we do needs lots of help here, but Americans have big hearts, and we try to do as much as we can for everyone. And that does include refugees -- people fleeing for their lives from their governments, they're so desperate, so cold and hungry and in great despair. It's a pretty grim scene. Now, Reverend Graham and I walked the refugee camp, seeing people -- children, adults -- shivering from this frigid Iraqi winter weather. We met a 90-year-old woman draped in blankets, desperately trying to get warm. There are a few heaters, but thousands and thousands of refugees are there, and winter has set in with a vengeance. So upon seeing this misery, Reverend Graham told his team to buy 2,000 heaters and get them there immediately. That's big. And he could do that because so many of you have generously donated to Samaritan's Purse. Your contributions take a big difference in people's lives. And of course Americans can't help everybody in every place, but we all try to do what we can and that's how I spent my weekend. And you'll see more of this journey to the Iraqi refugee camp in an upcoming special edition of "Fox Files" that's coming soon on TV. And of course I've already posted photographs on gretawire, so go see them. That's my "Off the Record" comment tonight. But if you have an important story or issue you think I should take "Off the Record," go to gretawire.com and tell us about it. And coming up, nearly two months Nick Diez went "On the Record" to tell you about is canceled healthcare plan. So, has he had any luck finding a new plan? Nick is back to tell you next, and don't forget tonight, 10:00 p.m., "Hannity." Sean's investigating into new Obamacare navigators who are accused of telling Americans to commit fraud. That's tonight, an all-new "Hannity" at 10:00 p.m. eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: Our next guest went "On the Record" in October just after Obamacare's rollout. His insurance company had canceled his plan, so nearly two months later, has he had any luck finding a new plan? Nick Diez joins us. Good evening.

NICK DIEZ, INSURANCE PLAN CANCELED DUE TO OBAMACARE: Hi, Greta.

VAN SUSTEREN: So, Nick, I know that your wife had breast cancer and so you had particular challenges in trying to find the right policy for your family. So, tell me, have you found that?

DIEZ: We have not.

VAN SUSTEREN: Well, you're coming up on December 23rd, I guess you know you have a few more days beyond that, but so, what's been the problem?

DIEZ: Well, there's been a number of problems, Greta. As you know, we tried to every way possible to try to find some coverage and every time we went in one direction, we got turned around and had to start trying again. Come to find out the other day that the insurance companies that are offering ACA plans in South Carolina are not offering the doctors and hospitals that we've been accustomed to using so now we're in a quandary. We don't know what to do, and to make matters worse, I found out from an insurance agent today that I was trying to work with that since we didn't get our application in by this past weekend, that we're definitely going to be without coverage January 1st, so we're going to go at least one month without any insurance coverage.

VAN SUSTEREN: You know, Nick, I find it absolutely cruel that your family has had to deal with cancer, and I know from just studying for the segment tonight, that your wife can't have the oncologist that she's been dealing with. You know, this whole idea that you could keep your doctor if you like it -- I mean, here we have life-threatening illnesses and we have a good relationship and a doctor who has kept your wife alive and treated her cancer, and now suddenly your lives are turned upside down. To me, it's appalling.

DIEZ: Yes, it's a terrible situation. You know, strike one, we found out that we could not keep our plan, strike two, we now find that we can't keep our doctors. I guess strike three is January 1 when we're going to lose coverage all together. It's just a terrible situation for somebody like me -- an average guy -- that is, you know, has been accustomed to doing what's right and kept our family covered for all these 35 years we've been married, and now we're at a loss for what to do.

VAN SUSTEREN: Now, there are two companies in South Carolina that provide insurance -- is that correct?

DIEZ: That is correct.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why isn't your oncologist on it? Is your oncologist not allowed onto the networks? Is there a problem -- or your wife's oncologist, I should say.

DIEZ: I don't know the answer to that. The oncologist is part of a large medical university here in South Carolina, and that's why we go to them, and as I understand it from talking with their finance department today, the entire medical university is not going to be part of the plans.

VAN SUSTEREN: And that would be a decision of the insurance company or the medical -- or the medical center?

DIEZ: I don't know the answer to that.

VAN SUSTEREN: All right, I suspect that it -- I mean, maybe they've made it untenable, but you know -- I know that doctors want to be part of successful plans so that they can help people and take care of the patients, and I know it's become very difficult. Nick, you know, I only -- I hope that things turn around for you on this. It doesn't look very likely in the short-run, but I do wish you and your family the best of luck. Thank you for joining us to tonight and keep us informed --

DIEZ: Thank you.

VAN SUSTEREN: -- will you?

DIEZ: (Inaudible).

VAN SUSTEREN: And thank you for joining us -- and thank you for being with us tonight. We're going to see you again tomorrow night right here at 7 p.m. eastern. Don't forget these three letters -- D-V-R. If you're getting home and turning on before Bill O'Reilly, pick up your DVR remote, get a -- set series recording. Good night from Washington.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5KRW-K0V1-DY0W-416C-00000-00Insurance Price Increases under Obamacare; Bipartisan Budget Plans Cuts Military Retirement Benefits; Police Hunt for 2 Killers Behind Deadly2013-12-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:00ZLexisNexisInsurance Price Increases under Obamacare; Bipartisan Budget Plans Cuts Military Retirement Benefits; Police Hunt for 2 Killers Behind DeadlyLanhamFULL TEXT

GRETA VAN SUSTEREN, FOX HOST: Do you sometimes wonder if the White House thinks you are stupid? And do you believe Press Secretary Jay Carney really believes this?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY CARNEY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Today, we are focusing on the savings that millions of consumers have already seen because of the health care law's provisions that produces more value for their health insurance premium dollars.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAN SUSTEREN: Most Americans don't agree with Jay Carney. You've heard many horror stories right here ON THE RECORD. And a new Associated Press poll shows 69 percent of the Americans say their premiums are going up. And 59 percent say their health plan and their co-payment or deductible is increasing.

Joining us is South Carolina Senator Tim Scott.

Nice to see you, sir.

SEN. TIM SCOTT, (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: Thank you, Greta. It's good to be back with you.

VAN SUSTEREN: So Jay Carney says thinks millions of Americans are seeing savings?

SCOTT: It is remarkable. There's no way in the world you can add tens of thousands of government employees, have a $400 million website and see premiums go down and not up. If you the look at the facts, the facts are simple. People in South Carolina -- Mr. Hucks from Greenville, South Carolina, sent me a letter. Talked to him for a little while. His premiums are going up by 75 percent. His deductible is going from $10,000 to $25,000. But his premiums are going from $450 to over $800 a month. If he wanted to go to a co-pay plan, lower deductable, $1500 a month for a family of four, he, his wife and two kids.

Premiums are skyrocketing. But the unfortunate part is premiums are about price. Deductibles and co-pay ands out-of-pocket expenses, those are about the costs. The costs are also exploding. And, unfortunately, we'll see more bad news once the seven million young people do not enroll. Next year, year two, the premiums will be based on the actuarial information, which will be dismal, which means we'll have worse rates and not better rates.

VAN SUSTEREN: For my life though, I can't figure it out. Jay Carney is a smart guy.

SCOTT: Yes.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why would he put his neck out on this? And maybe he would get lucky and the miracle would happen in the next six months and the price will come crashing down and make everybody flush with cash. Right now, it doesn't look like that. So why is he sticking his neck out and saying these things, great savings?

SCOTT: I have no idea. I can tell you this. If they find a way to control the price on the front end, it means the cost will rise on the back end. You can find a way to get an insurance company to provide an insurance policy that is not rated sufficient. It only means that some how, some way, taxpayers will pick up the tab on the back end.

VAN SUSTEREN: That is -- the American taxpayers have always been generous with the people who are down-and-out. And as we expand Medicaid, it will cost more.

SCOTT: Absolutely.

VAN SUSTEREN: Someone has to pick up the cost some place.

SCOTT: In South Carolina alone, if we were to expand Medicaid, we would see another $2 billion in costs over the next two years. There's just no way --

(CROSSTALK)

VAN SUSTEREN: What do you do about those people? I assume that people in South Carolina want healthy people -- people who are poor with health issues --

SCOTT: Absolutely.

VAN SUSTEREN: -- not to be able to get medical care. What do you do?

SCOTT: I was in Moncks Corner this morning talking about this very topic. One of the things I suggested we do to lower the cost of health insurance, not to talk about health care, but lower the cost of health insurance, we could allow for competition across the state lines and for small business owners to pool their employees together with other small business owners to reduce the rate by about 25 percent.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why didn't we do that?

SCOTT: That is one of the failures of the pre-Obamacare world. We had an opportunity to addressed things from a free-market perspective, including medical tort reform, and we didn't do it. Now, we're faced with a challenged of trying to reintroduce common sense into the marketplace. And it would work. We could also fund health care, insurance pools in states to provide those with preexisting conditions with more opportunities. The challenges get worse. If you are in a group plan, preexisting conditions are easily absorbed into a large group plan. When in an individual market, there is no group so you have to pay exceedingly higher rates to find your insurance. That is the challenged. That, coupled with out-of-pocket expenses, going from $6,000 or so to as high as 12,000, only means those folks who can't afford insurance, they get the free health care check up but they can't take care of the challenges that they find within that check up, what do we do next? What do they do next?

VAN SUSTEREN: There is a heartbreaker. But let me ask you about something else.

SCOTT: Yes.

VAN SUSTEREN: I want to talk to you about the bipartisan budget bill? The Senate has to vote on it this week. I think tomorrow. And under the bill, military retirement benefits will be cut by $6 billion over the next 10 years. Is it going to pass the Senate?

SCOTT: I think it will probably pass the Senate, watching and listening to my colleagues on the floor just now when we were voting. It seems the votes to get beyond cloture, the 60-vote threshold, will happen, which means you only need 51 for the underlying bill. The real challenge is, if you are a young guy, you sign up for the military and are 18 or 19 years old, you get a promise, that promise is we'll do what we're going to do for the next -- rest of your life. You retire at 42. And start looking for America to honor the promise, and we say, we made a promise but we're going to break that promise by changing the retirement benefit. And for a 42- year-old E-7, enlisted man, he loses about $75,000 in the next 20 years.

VAN SUSTEREN: That sounds horrible. I want to support our military in any particular way, but that's the same thing we are hearing like when they restructure in Detroit, when, all of the sudden, people lose pensions.

SCOTT: Yeah.

VAN SUSTEREN: That is always the situation. How do we accommodate them? What would you have done differently? Rather than penalize the military in this instance, what would you have done differently?

SCOTT: What I would love for us to have a serious conversation about in Congress is the fact that we have over 1200 duplicative programs that cost the taxpayers $200 billion. Here is an opportunity to reduce our spending and deal with our realities and challenges face on, and not put that on the back of our military.

VAN SUSTEREN: And for the life of me, I can't figure out why that never happens. Senator Tom Coburn has been talking about all the duplicate programs.

SCOTT: Yes.

VAN SUSTEREN: And the GAO has a report every year. And everybody just ignores it. I don't know why we pay for it. That's another expense. We pay for a report we ignore.

SCOTT: We have more Iraqi economic development plans that cost $26 million to American taxpayers.

VAN SUSTEREN: So why does that keep happening?

SCOTT: There's a number of bills that suggest how we can deal with it in a pragmatic approach. It never finds it --

VAN SUSTEREN: But why?

SCOTT: Well, I would say call Senator Reid. Everybody call Senator Reid and ask why he won't he let these votes on the floor?

VAN SUSTEREN: You blame him?

SCOTT: I blame the process. I certainly blame the leadership of the Senate today because, at the end of the day, we are not tackling the tough issues. One of the challenges, even in this budget deal, is we allowed ourselves to have two more years of spending, but how are we going to pay for it? The offsets happen over 10 years. Remember back to 2011, when we were going to pay for the increase in the debt ceiling over the next 10 years, well, here we sit 24 months later, looking for a new way to deal with the financial challenges.

VAN SUSTEREN: Are you going to vote for the bill?

SCOTT: I'm not going to vote for this bill tomorrow. There's just no way for -- I think it is a step forward. It's good that both sides are talking. That's good. We're having real pension reform. That's good. But there's two steps back. There's the ugly and bad. The bad is that we're paying for it over 10 years. The ugly is that we're asking our military to pay for it for us, and not taking care of our responsibilities by cutting spending. We are simply shifting who pays in our current active duty military. That's ugly.

VAN SUSTEREN: What happens when we get to the debt ceiling issue in February or March?

SCOTT: Hopefully, we won't have another one-year increase with 10-years to pay for it. Hopefully, we'll do something more logical by looking at the underlying debt, giving ourselves an opportunity to have a source conversation. It's good that Senator Murray and Congressman Ryan are having conversations. If we continue that, perhaps we can find a real solution that actually cut spending enough to have a discussion on the debt ceiling.

VAN SUSTEREN: Senator, always nice to see you, sir.

SCOTT: Thank you so much.

VAN SUSTEREN: Straight ahead, new information about some Obamacare navigators. Should there be a criminal investigation? What are the navigators doing and could it get you in trouble? Congressman Trey Gowdy is here next.

And you can "Hash It Out" with us. We know you have an opinion about this one. Will Obamacare save your family money in the long run or will it crush your finances? Tweet or post on Facebook right now using #great.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: This is a FOX News alert. The hunt is on right now for two killers behind a deadly mall carjacking. At an upscale shopping mall, a young couple out doing holiday shopping is suddenly attacked in a parking lot outside of a Nordstrom store. The husband had opened the car door for his wife and walked around to the driver's door when it happened.

WNYW FOX New York's Sharon Crowley joins us from the Short Hills Mall in New Jersey.

Tell me what is the latest?

SHARON CROWLEY, CORRESPONDENT, WNYW FOX NEW YORK: Yeah, what a sad story just before Christmas as well.

What you reported is true. It was just as the mall was closing. He and his wife were returning to their SUV and getting in the car. 30-year-old Dustin Friedlander, of Hoboken, New Jersey. He and his wife both attorneys. Just finished shopping. She is sitting in the passenger side and he's just about to get in the driver's side door when he's ambushed by two, police say, thugs who were trying to carjack his expensive SUV. They shot him in the head, police say, and sped off in his car. His wife was screaming. The mall, the Short Hills Mall, a very affluent, expensive, luxurious mall, was put in a lookdown for a short time. He was transported to the hospital but died a short time later.

Tonight, Greta, police have not found the gunmen. They are looking for two suspects who sped off in the stolen car and another vehicle that they were seen in, a green Subaru. There's an extensive reward being offered for their arrest.

Earlier, we had breaking developments on this story. The stolen SUV was found in Newark, Newark, New Jersey, in a high-crime area next to an abandoned home which sources tell us is well-known for car thieves. They often drop the stolen cars there in that area.

So one of the possibilities tonight they are looking at is whether they are connected to a larger car theft ring. Right now, no arrests have been made.

The Short Hills Mall has been reopened. We talked with shoppers today. Greta, people are on edge. Security here is very, very tight. And there is a visible police presence. There always is. But the mall is reviewing its security procedures and has added police officers.

And another important development, they will be looking at any security cameras in the mall-level parking lot or stores around there to see if that will assist them, Greta, in solving this crime.

VAN SUSTEREN: Sharon, for the life of me, I can't understand why they haven't released that videotape already. This is a manhunt for two killers. They could kill again. They've shown they are capable of killing. This happened Saturday night and the videotape -- the place has to be loaded with security cameras in the parking lot. Why aren't the videotapes released already so we can put them out there for people to help?

CROWLEY: Absolutely right. Greta, that it is something that -- the Essex County prosecutor's office is the lead investigator on this case. We've been in touch with them. That is certainly something you would think that would help in this case, especially the high-end retail stores, Nordstrom and Sak's Fifth Avenue. These stores you know are loaded with security cameras inside and outside of the building and in the parking lot. Certainly that would be helpful if we were able to see that. Unless, of course, police are closing in on exactly who they are looking for.

One of the things that investigators said in this case is that usually the carjackers, although carjacking is violent, they steal the car. They don't shoot and kill the driver as well. That is unusual. And in this area, Short Hills, Milburn, New Jersey, it is a very affluent, very low-crime area. So this is a highly unusual event in this area.

VAN SUSTEREN: I might add, when you carjack a car, unless you have gloves on, you would leave a lot clues and fibers, if you sneeze, anything, DNA all over the inside of the car, so that car could be a wealth of information to try to track down these two killers.

We'll stay on this story and Sharon will as well.

Thank you, Sharon.

CROWLEY: OK, thank you.

VAN SUSTEREN: Obamacare navigators telling you to break the law. What are they doing and why are they doing it? Congressman Trey Gowdy is here, coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: Are Obamacare navigators breaking the law? A new report shows many of them are telling you to commit fraud. The report claims some Obamacare navigators telling people to lie on their health care applications in order to get better credits and subsidies. Guess what? That is a fraud. That's illegal. You can go to jail for that stuff.

Congressman Trey Gowdy joins us.

Good evening, sir.

REP. TREY GOWDY, (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: Good evening. How are you?

VAN SUSTEREN: Very well.

Am I right this is one of the suspicions that navigators are telling people how to commit a crime?

GOWDY: It is more than a suspicion. There are at least two tapes that I'm aware of. One was lie about your finances and the other was lie about your preexisting habit of smoking, both of which would impact your premium you're your subsidy.

VAN SUSTEREN: And I am looking at the U.S. House of Representatives report. I have a copy right here. And I will read the part you were just talking about. It says, "Navigators from the Urban League of Dallas were captured on video encouraging applicants to lie on their health insurance applications so the applicants could qualify for tax subsidies. Navigators were also recording advising applicants to lie about smoking habits to obtain a lower monthly premium."

Has this been referred to the Department of Justice of to the local U.S. attorney?

GOWDY: I doubt it. Nothing much seems to get referred these days for criminal prosecution. I don't even know whether they've lost their job, Greta. I know the young lady who made the mistakes of answering Sean Hannity's questions on the phone lost her job. I don't even know if these two have lost their job. But there is no background check and it's 20 hours of training. You undergo more training to be a life guard at a reflection poll than you do to be a navigator. And you can take the test as many times as you need to. Think of how well you would have done in school if you could keep taking the test until you pass it.

The navigator thing -- it is a shame you have to have a navigator to access a federal program to begin with. Then, no background check and 20 hours of training and taking the test as many times as you want, and then you can council people to commit frauds once you want to enroll.

VAN SUSTEREN: It's basic law, for those who are unaware. If you participate and aid and abet someone in committing a crime, you are just as guilty as a principle. Every time you do it, it's another count. If you do it with five people as a navigator, those are five felony counts right there. Right?

GOWDY: Well, we can't even get the GAO -- yeah, you are right. It's aiding and abetting. And if you know about it, and don't report it, it's a felony. But we can't get anybody prosecuted by this Department of Justice. So hold out no hope. I will just settle if they don't get to keep their jobs and counsel more people.

VAN SUSTEREN: But why -- why did you have to go all the way to Justice. Why can't you have the U.S. attorney in Dallas or the first assistant to call them up and say convene a grand jury? You don't have to get permission from Eric Holder. If you start an investigation and Eric Holder suddenly stepped on it, from D.C. to Dallas, that would raise holy hell within the ranks of the U.S. attorneys.

GOWDY: It has happen before. But you are right. The U.S. attorney and the district in Texas that happens to be could do that. And for all I know, they may be working on it. I think it is a shame, if you have on tape somebody counseling someone else to commit a fraud against the taxpayers, and there is no sanction or consequence. It would be a nice start if you just lost your job before you got referred for criminal prosecutions.

VAN SUSTEREN: We should make note, when you talk about the subsidies, if you're trying to -- if they are lying about his or her income so they get a subsidy, that means taxpayers pay extra money out of their pocket to some insurance company. Taxpayers, they are the ones that suffer financially.

GOWDY: You have the whole concept of unjust enrichment. But, Greta, for whatever reason, people seem to treat government money differently than they do their own, and it is OK to lie to get a higher subsidy or I -- Yeah, we have a lot of issues in this country, morality being one of them. I just can't believe that someone -- the taxpayers are paying the salary for a navigator that's counseling someone to defraud taxpayers out of money. I would love to leave Congress and prosecute the case myself, and the one you referenced in the last segment as well

VAN SUSTEREN: Let me ask you about the contracts and the subpoena. I have a copy of a letter that was sent to Chairman Darrell Issa, and the letter is from Alfred Grasso and it's the MITRE Corporation. He's trying to explain why it is that he doesn't want to comply directly with the subpoena from the House Oversight Committee. He is one of the contractors. What is his excuse for not complying with a subpoena?

GOWDY: There is a contract that forbids him from making disclosures to third partnerships. But I've got news for Kathleen Sebelius, Congress is not a third party. And my guess is that gentlemen, if he hasn't sought legal counsel and concluded he needs to comply with this subpoena very shortly, will. Two contractors reached the right conclusion. Which if between Kathleen Sebelius and Darrell Issa, you are better off doing what Darrell Issa tells you to do.

VAN SUSTEREN: Will Congress and Chairman Issa put their foot down and get these documents? There's always such a long dance in getting them. If it is a subpoena, they should provide them no questions asked.

GOWDY: Yes, then we'll fight over the redactions. Lots of the documents are redacted. And then, Greta, you don't know what you don't know. So if the contractor gives information but it's not a total disclosure, we don't know what we don't have. Underlying your question is also, why does nothing ever happen to people who don't do what Congress tells them to do? That's a recurring conversation that you and I have. The fact that Kathleen Sebelius, if -- if told someone not to conform to a subpoena, even if they do, I would encourage Chairman Issa to still investigate it. To me, it is not alls well that ends well. If you counsel someone to impede a congressional investigation, even if they don't take your advice, I would love to see them investigated. And my suspicion is that my advice would be well received by Chairman Issa.

VAN SUSTEREN: The irony is they all work for us. The contractors are getting paid with our money as taxpayers. Kathleen Sebelius, secretary of HHS, works for us. We are the only ones who don't get the information. Everyone is taking our money and having secret contracts that we can't even see and we don't even know how they're spending our money. We don't even know what is in the contracts.

GOWDY: Not only are they taking your money but they're taking your personal information. This is what all of this is about, is whether or not your information is secure. And I have colleagues on the other side of the aisle who want to convene a special College of Cardinals to keep Darrell Issa from getting information so he can know whether or not your data is secure or not.

(CROSSTALK)

GOWDY: It's not just your money, it's also -- yes, ma'am.

VAN SUSTEREN: It is also your personal stuff.

Congressman, thank you very much. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to interrupt you. But thank you, sir.

GOWDY: Yes, ma'am. And have a good night.

VAN SUSTEREN: Thank you, too,

Coming up, he has the big and flashy ads and the big celebrities in his back pocket. But are young Americans now turning on President Obama, and why? That's next?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(SINGING)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: Now get ready to "Speed Read" your way through the news.

A big setback today for President Obama and NSA. Today, a federal judge ruling the NSA's domestic phone spying program unconstitutional. The ruling paves the way for future appeals and court challenges. And tomorrow, President Obama meets with the heads of all the big tech companies to talk about moving forward from the spying scandal.

And it's not over -- a new dangerous winter storm sweeping across America from the Midwest to the northeast. Many people are getting a second battering of wild winter weather. And tonight many places hit with even more snow. This latest flash is paralyzing much of the Midwest tonight. And are you ready to play "Who Wants to be a Millionaire." Well, you better grab a Mega Millions ticket -- the jackpot climbing all the way up to $586 million. That big drawing? That's tomorrow. And if nobody wins before Christmas, it could be a very merry holiday for someone because the jackpot could climb to $1 billion. And that's tonight's "Speed Read." And the flashy ads of big-name celebrities in a gigantic social media push. HHS is pulling out all the stops to get millennials -- yes, those are the young people -- to sign up for Obamacare. But do millennials want Obamacare or do they even -- do they even want President Obama in office anymore? A poll just out showing a majority of millennials disapprove of the president's performance. Forty-six percent disapprove of President Obama's job performance, while just 45 percent approve. And now, our panel going "On the Record" -- A.B. Stoddard from the Hill, John McCormack from the "Weekly Standard" and Susan Ferrechio from the "Washington Examiner." A.B., first to you -- your description of the Obamacare rollout is a turn off to the millennials, so how does Obama administration undo that turn off?

A.B. STODDARD, "THE HILL": Well it's going to take a lot of work. I mean, I think that this is a generation of kids who are well informed, that are internet savvy, they also are struggling to find an anchor in the middle class and get their first few jobs and establish themselves with some kind of financial security. They know, if they've read about this, that it's off to a rocky start if you -- just because you get into the web -- to the website -- doesn't mean you actually end up purchasing insurance. And they might've also found out that the non-compliance fee in the first year is only $95 and it's very difficult for the Internal Revenue Service to collect. So, all of the signals from the administration to these people are we can't handle what we promised. They have to do the reverse, they have to start talking about the benefits of getting insurance -- the ease of getting insurance. Otherwise, I think these people are going to say 'Sounds like there's a lot of waivers and extensions and problems, maybe we'll just sit it out and see what they come up -- it must be changing sometime soon.'

VAN SUSTEREN: John, so now we're going to have this sort of P.R. campaign where they're going to try and tell everybody this is great, all the millennials says it's fantastic.

JOHN MCCORMACK, "WEEKLY STAR": That's what they're going for, but I don't think any marketing campaign can really save them from this law. A there's one study out that said that 80 percent of people under the age of 30 are going to pay more for health insurance under Obamacare, even with the subsidies. So, unless you make less than 200 percent of the poverty level, you're definitely going to be worse off. So the real problem isn't marketing, it's just simple economics. I mean, you have to look at the fact that there are millions of people out there who didn't have health insurance because they thought it was a bad deal before Obamacare. They made it cost more, and why would they sign up for it now?

SUSAN FERRECHIO, "THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER": I agree with that and I also think if you look, there's another poll that says most young people feel like the law is not going to be around for much longer -- that it's going to end up being repealed or it's going to collapse. Why sign up for something that's not going to be there for them? I mean, they're willing to wait in line overnight for an iPhone which they're going to get and hold in their hand and have something for it, but for students -- people with student loans, their parents don't have as much money to help them out, you know, they're struggling to pay their rent, to pay their $100 a month cell phone bill. I looked at some of the costs for young people all around the country -- you're looking at costs 2, $300 a month for big deductibles, $5,000 for a plan that only covers 60% and you know I just -- for young people, it's not going to add up. I think it's going to be really tough to get them enrolled.

VAN SUSTEREN: So, what happens if they don't? Everybody's got such a grim view that nothing -- that you know they're not going to sign up, so with them not going to sign up, who's going to pay for this, A.B.?

STODDARD: Well, that's going to be a problem that's worked out in 2014. The prices for 2014 have been set, the insurance companies are going to look after March 31 at just how many people were enrolled. The administration said to sustain the program, they're looking at a risk balance of three to one -- one young healthy person to every three sick, risky elder people. If that doesn't work out, and that equation is out of whack, we're going to see prices rise in 2015 and that's how it's going to get paid for.

VAN SUSTEREN: Spike or ride? Spike or ride?

STODDARD: Well, I don't know. I mean, I don't know if we're going to be doing a taxpayer bailout of the insurance companies combined with higher prices or all higher premiums. I don't know how it's going to break up.

VAN SUSTEREN: What's the best news for Obama administration on Obamacare?

MCCORMACK: The best news -- I'm stumped. Honestly --

VAN SUSTEREN: You know, Susan, if there's any good news coming out of this?

FERRECHIO: Well, I would think that if they can find a way to help the insurance companies through these risk corridors where there's some money that the administration can use where they don't have to go through Congress, that might be able to sustain it for another year. And if they have you know see that Hollywood on their side trying to promote this thing, they may be able to get more people enrolled. I mean, they do have you know Hollywood backing them with the big promotional campaign -- it's possible.

VAN SUSTEREN: But I don't even see a lot of sympathy from the insurance companies. The insurance companies are trying to knock the -- you know, like Mayo Clinic and M.D. Anderson -- they're trying to keep them out of the mix because they're expensive place to get medical care. I mean, the insurance companies are not making them particularly sympathetic like you want to help them.

STODDARD: I think that's easy for the administration to dump on the insurance company -- companies -- when things go bad. Just like when President Obama had to admit the people who were self-insured and were promised they were going to get to keep their policy they elected, actually had just lost it and couldn't have it -- the law was never going to let them. It's easy to knock the insurance companies and say, 'Well, we had to make those -- we had to outlaw those plans because they were so terrible.'

VAN SUSTEREN: Yes, but isn't the president aligned with them -- I mean --

STODDARD: Oh, my God --

VAN SUSTEREN: -- isn't the president joined at the hip with the insurance companies? How can he blame the insurance companies:?

STODDARD: The insurance companies -- the insurance industry cannot collapse. They insure us. If it's not made right for them the whole thing collapses on itself -- this death spiral of price increases that everyone talks about as a worst-case scenario. We can't just blame the insurance companies. They've now taken in the sick. This has to work. And so the best news for the Obama administration in some states -- some of the -- you know, the percentage targets are being reached for enrollment -- those are largely in states that are running their own exchanges, not the ones that are under healthcare.gov. If they can somehow fit -- align -- the enrollment with the purchasing and make sure that more people are insured, and convince young people, they might meet their target numbers.

VAN SUSTEREN: All right, panel if you'll stand by, because we'll be back with you a little bit later. Straight ahead, did President Obama deliberately delay important regulations to keep his job? New evidence tonight points right to the Whitehouse. That's coming up next. Also, these men and women hitting the streets in Santa costumes. But then something went terribly wrong. More of this wild video up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: Now it's time to show you what we are watching. We've put together the most fantastic videos out there tonight. Take a look -- naughty or nice? Apparently not all Santas play by the same rules. This group getting very naughty, drawing punches and pushing each other to the ground, all of it caught on camera. Hundreds of people dressed as Santa hit the streets of New York City each year for SantaCon. It's mostly a pub crawl, but clearly this group of Santas hit the bottle a bit too hard. Talk about holiday spirit. And winter sports aren't just for humans. Check out this bird who apparently forgot he or she can fly. The bird turning a jar lid into a sled. Watch as this creature hops on board and slides right down the roof. Now that looks fun, but next time it'd probably be a lot easier just to use his wings. And this is the strangest yet coolest Christmas card our "On the Record" staff has seen in years. Meet the (Holderness) family.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

(SINGING CLIP)

(END VIDEOCLIP)

VAN SUSTEREN: Now, the "On the Record" staff wants me to make one of these, but I think I'll wait until the staff does its first. And that's what we are watching tonight. And coming up, new evidence that President Obama may have deliberately dragged his feet about something important to you just to get reelected. What was it? And is he any different from other presidents? Your "On the Record" political panel is back next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: President Obama delay important environmental regulations to keep his own job? Well there's new evidence he pushed back some EPA changes until after the 2012 election, but do all presidents do this essentially -- just play us? Our "On the Record" panel is back. And first (inaudible) is a "Washington Post" article suggested that the Obama administration has egregiously been playing the delay game to get reelected. What's the problem?

FERRECHIO: I think the important quote in that story was the word went out from the Whitehouse according to one administration official that they were not anxious to have these regulations under review because of the upcoming election. I mean, it says it all right there -- that they were really concerned about their reelection prospect. And it goes beyond just the environmental regulations. I think there's a lot of suspicion that the healthcare law was -- you know -- things were promised when maybe people realized those promises would not be kept because they wanted to preserve the president's -- you know -- how he could sell himself to voters. I mean, there was worried about him -- them -- changing, you know, the nuisances of how he explained the health care law because they were worried about reelection. And what it does is it cost him the trust of the public, and then as a consequence, Democrats overall are not trusted. And they're the ones who are going to be in the hot seat in 2014. This is a campaign now that rights itself. It's like -- do you trust these Democrats to be your senator or your representative.

VAN SUSTEREN: Is President Obama any worse, John, than other administrations that's put -- part one of my question -- the second part is pushing us off these regulations until after the election. I mean, Congress does it overtly. They put all deadlines after the election. I mean, the Obama administration's just doing something toward sneaky, under the table that Congress does overtly.

MCCORMACK: Well, I think putting controversial policy decisions until after an election is politics as usual. But, again, from a president who said he wasn't going to give us politics as usual. I mean, if you look at George W. Bush, who was more policy issues. You know, he tackled social security reform which went down in flames after the election. I think a lot of people don't think it was a coincidence that some even campaigns in Iraq -- the of Second Battle of Fallujah happened right after the election and not right before, I think people obviously -- if you lose the election, you lose the agenda. So when you're the president, you can sort of say to yourself, well, maybe I'm not doing this for a purely political reason, but I'm doing it in the long-run for the policy gains.

But I think right here what's interesting is that you actually have the "Post" saying this is much worse. The "Washington Post" reported that it was worse than its predecessors. And I think it's actually coming back to haunt him with the healthcare. You know, there's been a lot of complaints from the contractors who've been kind of quiet, you know, they don't want to get beaten up too bad, but when they have responded, why did things go wrong? They said well a lot of these regulations went out late, you know. There have been with the website in terms of how they structured it whether you can browse it -- well these decisions weren't made until after the election. So I think really a lot of the problems with the healthcare website -- we might find this out in the long -- after we do more investigating -- that this is because of these political decisions which have really come back to bite the president.

VAN SUSTEREN: A.B., does he have any stock -- any credibility stock -- because he's, you know -- the healthcare is a nightmare and he doesn't have a lot of friends on Capitol Hill. What does he have going for him?

STODDARD: Well, he has three more years. And that's really about it at this point. He has an economy I would mention that you know is going in the right direction and if it were to make considerable gains in the next 18 months or so, I think -- I believe -- that could turn things around. For him, ultimately --

VAN SUSTEREN: Except, except for (inaudible) there's one problem though and that's that he's got to get -- if he loses the Senate, he's got nothing.

STODDARD: Oh, no, and that's possible. Like I said, I don't know that the economy will make gains to convince the public that he did the right think until after the midterm elections anyway. I think between now and the next year, we're going to look at a closer scrutiny of his regulations process - - what is he going to do before -- what will he release in 2014 before the midterms or will he release afterwards? He's going to have a night and day oversight of the Affordable Care Act. He is really in a bind right now because there's no path out -- there's nothing else to talk about. They can keep talking about immigration reform, but it's not something Republicans are interested in as a party. Maybe sometime late summer but maybe not. And so for President Obama, the only thing he can do is work night and day to restore his credibility on healthcare. I really think his entire presidency is tied to whether that turns around or fails.

VAN SUSTEREN: Panel, thank you very much. And let's all go "Off the Record" for just a minute. On Thursday, I flew to Iraq with Reverend Franklin Graham of Samaritan's Purse and went to a Syrian refugee camp in Iraq. I did it for two important reasons -- first of all, I want to do a good job for you. I want you to know what's going on in the world -- that's my job -- and I do a better job for you when I see something firsthand -- not just from reading about it on an internet or off a computer screen. Second, I go because I care, and I know you care too. Yes, things aren't perfect here at home and we do needs lots of help here, but Americans have big hearts, and we try to do as much as we can for everyone. And that does include refugees -- people fleeing for their lives from their governments, they're so desperate, so cold and hungry and in great despair. It's a pretty grim scene. Now, Reverend Graham and I walked the refugee camp, seeing people -- children, adults -- shivering from this frigid Iraqi winter weather. We met a 90-year-old woman draped in blankets, desperately trying to get warm. There are a few heaters, but thousands and thousands of refugees are there, and winter has set in with a vengeance. So upon seeing this misery, Reverend Graham told his team to buy 2,000 heaters and get them there immediately. That's big. And he could do that because so many of you have generously donated to Samaritan's Purse. Your contributions take a big difference in people's lives. And of course Americans can't help everybody in every place, but we all try to do what we can and that's how I spent my weekend. And you'll see more of this journey to the Iraqi refugee camp in an upcoming special edition of "Fox Files" that's coming soon on TV. And of course I've already posted photographs on gretawire, so go see them. That's my "Off the Record" comment tonight. But if you have an important story or issue you think I should take "Off the Record," go to gretawire.com and tell us about it. And coming up, nearly two months Nick Diez went "On the Record" to tell you about is canceled healthcare plan. So, has he had any luck finding a new plan? Nick is back to tell you next, and don't forget tonight, 10:00 p.m., "Hannity." Sean's investigating into new Obamacare navigators who are accused of telling Americans to commit fraud. That's tonight, an all-new "Hannity" at 10:00 p.m. eastern.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VAN SUSTEREN: Our next guest went "On the Record" in October just after Obamacare's rollout. His insurance company had canceled his plan, so nearly two months later, has he had any luck finding a new plan? Nick Diez joins us. Good evening.

NICK DIEZ, INSURANCE PLAN CANCELED DUE TO OBAMACARE: Hi, Greta.

VAN SUSTEREN: So, Nick, I know that your wife had breast cancer and so you had particular challenges in trying to find the right policy for your family. So, tell me, have you found that?

DIEZ: We have not.

VAN SUSTEREN: Well, you're coming up on December 23rd, I guess you know you have a few more days beyond that, but so, what's been the problem?

DIEZ: Well, there's been a number of problems, Greta. As you know, we tried to every way possible to try to find some coverage and every time we went in one direction, we got turned around and had to start trying again. Come to find out the other day that the insurance companies that are offering ACA plans in South Carolina are not offering the doctors and hospitals that we've been accustomed to using so now we're in a quandary. We don't know what to do, and to make matters worse, I found out from an insurance agent today that I was trying to work with that since we didn't get our application in by this past weekend, that we're definitely going to be without coverage January 1st, so we're going to go at least one month without any insurance coverage.

VAN SUSTEREN: You know, Nick, I find it absolutely cruel that your family has had to deal with cancer, and I know from just studying for the segment tonight, that your wife can't have the oncologist that she's been dealing with. You know, this whole idea that you could keep your doctor if you like it -- I mean, here we have life-threatening illnesses and we have a good relationship and a doctor who has kept your wife alive and treated her cancer, and now suddenly your lives are turned upside down. To me, it's appalling.

DIEZ: Yes, it's a terrible situation. You know, strike one, we found out that we could not keep our plan, strike two, we now find that we can't keep our doctors. I guess strike three is January 1 when we're going to lose coverage all together. It's just a terrible situation for somebody like me -- an average guy -- that is, you know, has been accustomed to doing what's right and kept our family covered for all these 35 years we've been married, and now we're at a loss for what to do.

VAN SUSTEREN: Now, there are two companies in South Carolina that provide insurance -- is that correct?

DIEZ: That is correct.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why isn't your oncologist on it? Is your oncologist not allowed onto the networks? Is there a problem -- or your wife's oncologist, I should say.

DIEZ: I don't know the answer to that. The oncologist is part of a large medical university here in South Carolina, and that's why we go to them, and as I understand it from talking with their finance department today, the entire medical university is not going to be part of the plans.

VAN SUSTEREN: And that would be a decision of the insurance company or the medical -- or the medical center?

DIEZ: I don't know the answer to that.

VAN SUSTEREN: All right, I suspect that it -- I mean, maybe they've made it untenable, but you know -- I know that doctors want to be part of successful plans so that they can help people and take care of the patients, and I know it's become very difficult. Nick, you know, I only -- I hope that things turn around for you on this. It doesn't look very likely in the short-run, but I do wish you and your family the best of luck. Thank you for joining us to tonight and keep us informed --

DIEZ: Thank you.

VAN SUSTEREN: -- will you?

DIEZ: (Inaudible).

VAN SUSTEREN: And thank you for joining us -- and thank you for being with us tonight. We're going to see you again tomorrow night right here at 7 p.m. eastern. Don't forget these three letters -- D-V-R. If you're getting home and turning on before Bill O'Reilly, pick up your DVR remote, get a -- set series recording. Good night from Washington.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5B31-BH41-DXH2-60TC-00000-00Insurance Price Increases under Obamacare; Bipartisan Budget Plans Cuts Military Retirement Benefits; Police Hunt for 2 Killers Behind Deadly Mall Carjacking; Obamacare Navigators Urging Applicants to Lie on Obamacare;2013-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:00ZLexisNexisFOX ON THE RECORD WITH GRETA VAN SUSTEREN7:00 PM ESTTim Scott, Sharon Crowley, Trey Gowdy, A.B. Stoddard, John McCormack, Susan Ferrechio, Nick DiezNEWSDomestic121601cb.260Insurance Price Increases under Obamacare; Bipartisan Budget Plans Cuts Military Retirement Benefits; Police Hunt for 2 Killers Behind Deadly Mall Carjacking; Obamacare Navigators Urging Applicants to Lie on Obamacare;Greta Van Susteren

GRETA VAN SUSTEREN, FOX HOST: Do you sometimes wonder if the White House thinks you are stupid? And do you believe Press Secretary Jay Carney really believes this?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY CARNEY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Today, we are focusing on the savings that millions of consumers have already seen because of the health care law's provisions that produces more value for their health insurance premium dollars.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

VAN SUSTEREN: Most Americans don't agree with Jay Carney. You've heard many horror stories right here ON THE RECORD. And a new Associated Press poll shows 69 percent of the Americans say their premiums are going up. And 59 percent say their health plan and their co-payment or deductible is increasing.

Joining us is South CarolinaSenator Tim Scott.

Nice to see you, sir.

SEN. TIM SCOTT, (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: Thank you, Greta. It's good to be back with you.

VAN SUSTEREN: So Jay Carney says thinks millions of Americans are seeing savings?

SCOTT: It is remarkable. There's no way in the world you can add tens of thousands of government employees, have a $400 million website and see premiums go down and not up. If you the look at the facts, the facts are simple. People in South Carolina -- Mr. Hucks from Greenville, South Carolina, sent me a letter. Talked to him for a little while. His premiums are going up by 75 percent. His deductible is going from $10,000 to $25,000. But his premiums are going from $450 to over $800 a month. If he wanted to go to a co-pay plan, lower deductable, $1500 a month for a family of four, he, his wife and two kids.

Premiums are skyrocketing. But the unfortunate part is premiums are about price. Deductibles and co-pay ands out-of-pocket expenses, those are about the costs. The costs are also exploding. And, unfortunately, we'll see more bad news once the seven million young people do not enroll. Next year, year two, the premiums will be based on the actuarial information, which will be dismal, which means we'll have worse rates and not better rates.

VAN SUSTEREN: For my life though, I can't figure it out. Jay Carney is a smart guy.

SCOTT: Yes.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why would he put his neck out on this? And maybe he would get lucky and the miracle would happen in the next six months and the price will come crashing down and make everybody flush with cash. Right now, it doesn't look like that. So why is he sticking his neck out and saying these things, great savings?

SCOTT: I have no idea. I can tell you this. If they find a way to control the price on the front end, it means the cost will rise on the back end. You can find a way to get an insurance company to provide an insurance policy that is not rated sufficient. It only means that some how, some way, taxpayers will pick up the tab on the back end.

VAN SUSTEREN: That is -- the American taxpayers have always been generous with the people who are down-and-out. And as we expand Medicaid, it will cost more.

SCOTT: Absolutely.

VAN SUSTEREN: Someone has to pick up the cost some place.

SCOTT: In South Carolina alone, if we were to expand Medicaid, we would see another $2 billion in costs over the next two years. There's just no way --

(CROSSTALK)

VAN SUSTEREN: What do you do about those people? I assume that people in South Carolina want healthy people -- people who are poor with health issues --

SCOTT: Absolutely.

VAN SUSTEREN: -- not to be able to get medical care. What do you do?

SCOTT: I was in Moncks Corner this morning talking about this very topic. One of the things I suggested we do to lower the cost of health insurance, not to talk about health care, but lower the cost of health insurance, we could allow for competition across the state lines and for small business owners to pool their employees together with other small business owners to reduce the rate by about 25 percent.

VAN SUSTEREN: Why didn't we do that?

SCOTT: That is one of the failures of the pre-Obamacare world. We had an opportunity to addressed things from a free-market perspective, including medical tort reform, and we didn't do it. Now, we're faced with a challenged of trying to reintroduce common sense into the marketplace. And it would work. We could also fund health care, insurance pools in states to provide those with preexisting conditions with more opportunities. The challenges get worse. If you are in a group plan, preexisting conditions are easily absorbed into a large group plan. When in an individual market, there is no group so you have to pay exceedingly higher rates to find your insurance. That is the challenged. That, coupled with out-of-pocket expenses, going from $6,000 or so to as high as 12,000, only means those folks who can't afford insurance, they get the free health care check up but they can't take care of the challenges that they find within that check up, what do we do next? What do they do next?

VAN SUSTEREN: There is a heartbreaker. But let me ask you about something else.

SCOTT: Yes.

VAN SUSTEREN: I want to talk to you about the bipartisan budget bill? The Senate has to vote on it this week. I think tomorrow. And under the bill, military retirement benefits will be cut by $6 billion over the next 10 years. Is it going to pass the Senate?

SCOTT: I think it will probably pass the Senate, watching and listening to my colleagues on the floor just now when we were voting.
